case_vignette: A 7-year-old female presents for evaluation of facial rash that began three days ago. The patient's mother reports four days before the rash began, the patient had some fevers and thigh muscle aches. Mother notes many other children at the school have had a similar rash. On examination, on the bilateral cheeks are bright pink red lacy reticulated erythematous patches with sparing of the perioral and mesolabial fold with similar faint patches on the bilateral upper arms. No lesions are appreciated in oral mucosa. Patient is up to date with vaccinations.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.

I have a facial rash that started three days ago, and before that, I had fevers and muscle aches in my thighs.

No, I haven't been taking any medications or supplements recently.

No, my family members haven't had a similar rash or medical condition.
Final Diagnosis: Meningitis.
